speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: We'll hear argument in Jackson against the Birmingham Board of Education. Mr. Dellinger.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Of course, the question is whether -- that -- that may be true, but there would be an administrative remedy. The question here is a private cause of action for damages. 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Even -- even assuming the - - the validity of your premise, you still have another step.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I thought -- I thought that Cannon -- we've -- we've allowed Cannon to stay on the books, but I thought we have sworn off the kind of creation of -- of implied remedies that Cannon exemplifies.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It's very -- it's very useful, I'm sure, but it -- it could be very disruptive also, I am sure. If I were -- if I were a coach, one of the first things -- especially a coach of a women's team in high school, one of the first things I would do would be to complain about not -- not getting enough facilities. This would make it a lot more difficult to fire me whether - - whether I'm a lousy coach or not. You -- you would have to think twice before you fire me because I would have a retaliation claim.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Some of them specifically provide for retaliation, don't they?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Why do they do that if, as you assert, the mere word discrimination embraces it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Do you think that it -- it is a reasonable description of what happened -- he was fired for complaining about his girls' team not getting enough facilities -- that he was, on the basis of sex, excluded from participation in, denied benefits of, or subjected to discrimination under an education program?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Do you think that -- that remotely describes what happened to this coach?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But -- but that's again the question of the substantive scope of the provision, and that's different from whether there was a congressional intent to create a private cause of action for this sort of violation. And was it -- Virginia Bankshares and so forth tells us that this is not the heyday of prior cause of actions anymore. You have to show that there's a congressional intent in the Spending Clause to create a private cause of action for damages.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: And that's -- that's quite separate from - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- from this -- from the question of substantive liability.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Yes, but it's separate enough from discrimination that in other statutes, although Congress does create a cause of action for discrimination, it goes out of its way to create a separate cause of action for retaliation. It's sufficiently separate, and if it is that sufficiently separate, it doesn't seem to me that you could clearly say that -- that when the State signed on to receiving Federal funds under title IX, they should have known that this door to litigation was being 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 opened to them. Yes, litigation for -- for discrimination against -- against female athletes, but not -- not discrimination suits alleging retaliation. That's a whole, new area.

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Well, but there was -- there was -- let's go back to this for just a moment -- an administrative remedy available for retaliation expressly under the regs?

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: And did this petitioner seek an administrative remedy at all?

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: What would the administrative remedy have allowed here - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: -- had it been sought?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Do they have any other sanction? Because the notion of an administrative remedy ordinarily would be a remedy for the individual who's complaining. But as I understand it, this administrative process, this detailed administrative process, leads only to one sanction, the one you have described as draconian.

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: So that's it. It would not have permitted a restoration of the job to the --

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: -- petitioner.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Well, if we don't accept - - let's assume, just for the sake of argument, that -- that 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 we're having trouble accepting the -- the analysis that it is a violation of the statute in the statute's own terms. You then made the argument that, in fact, you should recognize retaliation as a claim because in the context of -- of school students and so on, if you don't allow retaliation, the teachers are not going to blow the whistle, and if the teachers blow the whistle, the statute is going to be a dead letter.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: So -- so the -- the argument is you -- you should recognize this as a necessity. That, it seems to me, still goes back to Justice O'Connor's question. Why do we have to recognize a private cause of action as opposed to the government allowing an administrative remedy? And I thought you were leading up to saying the administrative remedy simply isn't effective because it's so draconian that, in fact, they don't impose it, or for some other reason. So my question is, is there an argument to say that the administrative remedy simply is not good enough to preclude -- to -- to deter retaliation and that's why you've got to have a private cause of action?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: What's -- what are the facts? 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 What's the empirical evidence for that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Do you know if administrative sanctions have been imposed under title IX against schools?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Have funds --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- have funds -- Mr. Dellinger, have funds ever been withdrawn from any school because of a violation of - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- title IX?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That could be because - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- the sanction is so draconian that nobody in his right mind is not going to rehire the coach. Of course, they're going to rehire. I -- I find it hard to believe why a draconian sanction is ineffective. 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It seems to me it's -- it's overwhelmingly effective. You tell the school you either rehire the coach or we're cutting off your money.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Is it hard to decide what they're going to do?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: And I can't imagine anyone who would want such a sanction. Which doesn't help - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- the girls on the team.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, you're saying the coach cares more about it than the Government does?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, if -- if the Government is charged with -- with just spending the funds and doesn't think that this is worth its time, why should there be a private cause of action - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- when -- when a private cause of action is harder for us to imply than it -- than it is to an administrative remedy?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Mr. - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Mr. Gornstein, do you have any light to shed on the extent to which administrative sanctions have ever been imposed against schools and - - and the feasibility of going that route?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: They have been under title VI?

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Do you take the position that what occurred here can amount to a direct violation of the statute as discrimination?

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Why would Congress then in some statutes expressly cover retaliation and in others not? I mean, that's a little odd, isn't it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It rules out this one, but it doesn't rule out the main -- look it, this is a weird kind of retaliation claim. Usually the retaliation claim is the person who has been discriminated against complains about the discrimination, and for that complaint, the person who was discriminated against is demoted or not promoted, or whatever. That's -- that's the classic retaliation claim. And that classic claim is surely covered by -- on the basis of that person's sex. If - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: What was the date of the Sullivan case?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And -- and you think that we take the same approach to implied causes of action today that we took in 1969?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: And we certainly did not with a Spending Clause case.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I don't know what case it is, but one of our cases, the argument was precisely made that the statute before us had been enacted by Congress before we had set our face against implied causes of action, and therefore, we should interpret that statute the way we used to in 1969, and we rejected that argument. We said that our new rule, as to when you find implied causes of action, will be applied to all statutes, whether they were enacted by a Congress that -- that thought we would go skipping along forever as we did in 1969 or -- or not. And -- and that's what you're asking us to do here.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Just because Congress in -- in the -- at the time this statute was enacted believed in the existence of a Supreme Court that would readily find implied causes of action, we -- we have to do that for all these old statutes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But what about Virginia - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: What about Virginia Bankshares?

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Well, it -- it's arguable except that Mr. Jackson was not discriminated against because of his gender.

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: -- exactly like title VII, but - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And that's where you hang. You -- you really think Congress, when it enacted title IX, paid close attention and said -- instead of saying no person in the United States shall on the basis of that person's sex be excluded from participation, you think somebody had -- had suggested that language, and they said, oh, no, no, no, that would make it too narrow. We have to take out that person's. I -- I don't -- it doesn't strike me as a -- as an obvious import of not including the word that person's sex. It's a very natural way to write it: no person in the United States shall on the basis of sex.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Mr. Gornstein, what implication would there be, if we took the view of the circuit here, for Federal employment? Title VII does have a discrete retaliation provision, but it doesn't with respect to Federal employees, if I understand.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Are punitive damages available under title IX?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Thank you, Mr. Gornstein. Mr. Thomas.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: How often has OCR come to the school district in question under title IX? There are many statutes that - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- OCR administers. 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: How does he differ -- how does he differ from the renter in Sullivan who was complaining about the refusal to sell or lease property to African Americans? He wanted to lease his property, and as a result, he was thrown out of the club. And this Court said he could maintain that suit.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Well, what -- what do you make of the -- the point that Mr. Dellinger stressed and others have stressed that, in fact, there is no administrative remedy in the real world? It's -- it's -- there -- there have never -- there has never been an instance in which funds have been withheld.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: May I ask you with respect to that, is OCR so different from other agencies that have to pick and choose because they simply don't have the resources to enforce? Now, how often does OCR, in fact, go in and investigate? How many times do they say, well, 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 that's low priority for us, girls' soccer or girls' basketball, and we have bigger fish to fry?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But that wasn't my question. My question is of the universe of complaints that are made under title IX, how many does OCR actually follow up, or isn't it strapped for resources so that it can't, however much it may want to, come in the way you described?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: And that was the very reason for recognizing a private right of action because the - - the requirement, the anti-discrimination requirement, would be a dead letter if you didn't have people who could enforce it.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Yes, but the -- the argument that's being raised is whether we're talking about the 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 person who is listed in the statute as the primary beneficiary of the anti-discrimination statute or whether we're talking about the teacher who blows the whistle and so on -- the -- the argument is unless you allow this teacher or this whistle blower to -- to bring the private action, your statute is a dead letter, that the -- that if -- if -- once you recognize a private action, you've either got to recognize this kind of private action or you can forget the whole thing. That's the argument, and - - and so simply to say, well, they're not within the -- the primary ambit of benefit of the statute is -- is not to the point of the argument.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Well, that's -- to say trust me is -- is not an answer. Cannon is one thing, a woman in her 30's. A sixth-grader who is told she can't play on 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 a team because there's none for girls is hardly similarly situated and the law won't be enforced as to her unless you have someone who is best positioned to know what is going on, who is the coach.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: The -- the point is if you say to the school, you cannot retaliate against someone because a complaint has been made, that's a powerful incentive for the school not to retaliate against someone and to do something about the discrimination.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Why wasn't it in the regulations of the agency spelled out rather clearly - - the -- the agency that says, Congress has told us to implement this statute, here are our regulations and our regulations are you don't retaliate?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: The regulations didn't say anything about a private cause of action, did it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And the statute didn't say anything about a private cause of action.

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: But the regulation did tell the school not to retaliate in effect. Tell me, does the record disclose what happened to the petitioner, Jackson? What -- what has been the result of all this? Does the record tell us that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Does it tell us that he was removed as coach?

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Does the record tell us that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Can I ask you a legal question, nothing to do with, you know, practicalities?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: But suppose you go back to the very old, bad days of the 1950's in the South, the '60's. They pass some civil rights legislation. A lot of legislation was passed in the '60's. Now, under that civil rights legislation, imagine an individual had been kept out of a restaurant or he'd been treated physically badly, not because of his race. He was white, but he was associating with people who were black. And they both go into the restaurant and they both are refused service. Maybe they're beaten up. I mean, both of them. Now, can the white individual bring a lawsuit under the -- the civil rights statute? I've always thought the answer to that question is, of course, he can. Would you -- do you think it's the contrary answer?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Yes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Yes, of course.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: So therefore - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Is this a civil rights statute that provides for a private cause of action? I -- I want to know what the hypothetical is.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I'd -- I'd like to -- I'm thinking of various civil rights statutes which make it 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 unlawful to describe -- to -- to discriminate. And now, I agree with you on that answer. The white person could bring a lawsuit on the basis of someone else's race because he's being discriminated against not because of his own race, but because he's being -- he's associated with people who are being discriminated against. I agree with your answer. And so my question is if that's so and if we have a long history here of the words, on the basis of sex, including retaliation not on the basis of my sex, but retaliation on the basis of someone else's sex -- that's what I've complained of -- why isn't this the same thing And to get out my whole question -- there are two parts -- why isn't this the same thing? And the second part is, because I think it is the same thing - - the second part is once it is included in 1981 -- in -- is it 1681(a)?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Once we include this in 1681(a), that's the end of this case because Sandoval then supports the other side. It doesn't support you. All right. That's my question.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Well, yes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: So you -- you go ahead. I'm doing it purely as a matter of logic. I'm saying the old civil rights cases make clear it doesn't have to be on the basis of your own race. History makes clear that retaliation on the basis of someone else's race does fit within -- or gender does fit within 1681, and then that's the end of the case. So I would like your response to that logic.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Of course, you say it's not there, but the agencies interpreting the statute thought it was there. Isn't that correct?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But it's the - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: No, but their reading of the statute was that the word discrimination included a retaliation claim. That's the kind of regulations they drafted on the basis of their understanding of what Congress intended by using the word -- the words in this statute.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: You cannot use the regulation that goes beyond the meaning of the statute. That's what that holds. But a regulation interpreting what the statute itself provides is in a different ball park. And that's what I understand these regulations to have done, to say what the agencies thought the statute itself meant.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Well -- I mean, Sandoval is very clear. It's a very clear opinion in my view. Very clear. And the key language I thought is, the language statutes that focus on the person regulated rather than individuals protected create no implication of an intent to confer the private right. So they're looking at disparate impact and disparate impact, according to the majority -- I was in the dissent -- did not intend to protect the person discriminated against, but was a way of regulating people so they wouldn't intentionally discriminate. I can understand that. But I apply the same -- I didn't agree with it, but I can understand it. The -- the -- I apply the same reasoning here. The reasoning here is that this retaliation thing is not trying to protect university behavior one whit more than the whole underlying thing is trying to protect university behavior. This is about victims. Retaliation and being fired is about victims. And so given Sandoval, then we have the history, we have the language, and we have that sentence from Sandoval. And all that suggests -- it goes into 1681(a), in which case Sandoval says, a private right of action, given Cannon, would be inferred. Now, what's -- what's -- that's how -- I'm tracing out the logic of the thing. So I want to see what 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 you say.

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: We -- we can't -- you don't base your argument on giving some legal effect to denial of certiorari - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Thank you.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: It had never anticipated a 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 private right of action, even though it read the Cannon opinion, which was written some 20 years ago? Maybe more than that. I don't remember.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: There were some later cases that cast a good deal of doubt on whether we would apply Cannon anymore.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: But Congress itself has adopted the rule set forth in Cannon.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: It said in this statute we do, having in mind that title VI would be interpreted in the identical way - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- title VII -- VI proscribing race discrimination in all Federal programs. So it said these statutes aimed at race discrimination, sex discrimination do have a -- a private right of action, 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 and that was the holding of this Court.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Well, it seems to me that if you're talking about the sixth grade soccer team, realistically the only one who is going to know anything -- enough and be brave enough to complain will be the teacher. And if you cut the teacher out, then forget it. You have nice words on paper and they'll never be enforced.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: And OCR says, as it usually does, we're too busy. Sorry.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Congress didn't give us enough money to do the job.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Do we know that? I mean, do we have any idea how effective the enforcement of OCR is? Just because they haven't cut off funds - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- they may well not have cut off funds because anybody who gets a directive from them 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 will hop to it.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And do they call more than infrequently?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: This is your personal testimony.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: There is -- there is much testimony on the other side that says we call and call and they don't come.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: How many title IX complaints in your -- in your experience? You mentioned one. Is there any other?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Two? In how many years?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Two in 20-something years.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Thank you, Mr. Thomas. Mr. Newsom.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Do we -- do we have any -- any empirical evidence as to -- as to what they have thus leveraged?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: The -- the other side says, look, dead letter. What do we know about such life as there may be in the letter?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: You -- you don't concede the point that it is the role of this Court to determine whether agencies are inefficient or not - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- and if they are inefficient to -- to raise up private attorneys general to -- to fill the void?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: All right. If they're not relevant, do you think that the regulation which provides -- do you think it's unlawful?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Okay. If you don't contest the validity of it and you think it's lawful, do you think it's doing something other than interpreting 1681(a)?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: What -- what is it doing? 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Why is that, do you think?

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Is it because no remedy is available, or is it because there are just very few instances giving rise to such?

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Do we decide this case on the assumption that there was retaliation here by virtue of a complaint of violation of title IX?

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: We should decide it on that assumption? 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Like the choice it made in 1982, very spare statute. When Congress got to title IX, it knew about Sullivan and so it -- this -- this statute in its breadth and its simplicity bears a striking resemblance to the old pattern in 1981 and 1982 and 1983. So if you say to me, look at the closest model, it would be that and not the more detailed civil rights legislation 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 that came in '64 and '65.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: It says if you're thrown out of the club because you champion the rights of a black man, you have a right to sue under this statute.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Yes, but it did construe the word discrimination, didn't it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: On account of race is in it. Right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: It seems to me they would get it when Congress says, and here's the statute, very spare, and agency, you get up guidelines, that any responsible school board would say, well, we've got only one sentence in the statute. We better look at the regulations to find out what's required.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But it's -- we're not talking about the procedure, I mean, what procedural moves. What must you do to comply? And it has in there you don't retaliate. So you mean that a board could responsibly 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 take the position, well, the -- the regulations tell us we don't retaliate, but when we're not faced with any agency breathing down our neck, all we have is a teacher in front of us, then we can retaliate? I mean, they must have known the statute meant don't retaliate.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: I -- I really don't get that. If the rule is don't retaliate and if we investigate, that's one of the things we're going -- that's going to be on our checklist. But the substantive rule is don't retaliate.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Yes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Thank you, Mr. Newsom.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Mr. Dellinger, you have about 3 and a half minutes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Other statutes do it separately.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Other statutes don't view the one as -- as being incorporated in the other.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: There are no vagaries in private enforcement. Private attorneys general always act in the interest of the whole polity. There are no vagaries there.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Thank you, Mr. Dellinger. The case is submitted.
